entry.title: The Tech Stack is READY - There is so much beyond that. (TechEd 2025 presentation - Community talk)
entry.content:
Hi All

I had the pleasure of sharing some insights on AI journey for customers and partners at SAPTeched 2025 Berlin.

Let me share (the best I can in a BLOG) the content of my session.

I started by laying out that the presentation was based on a previous blog: The AI Stack Is Ready â€” Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technology . It is worth reading for context but I diggeed deeper in my TechEd session.

Let's dive in.

From a technology perspective, a GenAI (agent building) stack needs to provide the following capabilities:

  • Flexibility of choice of LLMs
  • Secure AI
  • RAG scenarios
  • Agent Building
  • Tool supporting
  • Orchestration

And we are there. Most platforms support that, at least in some way. That is true for SAP BTP and many others.

So we can consider that, the basic tools needed are provided. We can and should be able to start building.

Particularly around SAP, the latest TechEd announcements highlight the fast pace of innovation. More and more is coming.

MCP Support + ABAP LLM

RPT-1 and many other nice improvements

From a LLM perspective, the models keep getting better both in raw performance, Speed and cost.

As they keep getting better, a wrong approach would to say, the current models are not good enough or that we will decide to wait for next version. Believe me, you can get GPT6 performance today..... Let me explain.

Welcome TEST TIME COMPUTE

By applying some techniques that basically force the model to work harder at the question, will increase the performance.

An example of this is to ask for a brief answer vs compare that to an application that first determines a plan, proof it, execute it, revise and summarize the response. This is the principle of reasoning that are now more and more embedded in the SOTA (state of the art) LLMs, but you can keep pushing further....

SO, WHAT IS THE POINT MR. LEO???

Lets focus the discussion elsewhere. THE PROBLEM IS NO LONGER A TECHNICAL ONE.

Reality check

There are multiple reasons why that is the case. FIRST ONE is that the title of the article is misleading: It should be written 95% of the companies fail to demonstrate value. Sure a good chunk of that is due to use cases that delivered no or little value, true, but there is more to that story. 

In short:

  • Expectations are often not properly set;
  • It is natural that we get a high number if vailures - We are all experimenting and in this space, fail fast is the norm
  • There often a suboptimal approach (more on that later)
  • AND YES, it is hard to demonstrate value (methodology and tooling)

Lets set expectations right on very common misconceptions:

In ABAP you write 3 * 3 and the result will ALWAYS be 9 - This is deterministic

In GenAI (like with humans) it is probabilistic. The answer is 9 with 99.9999% prob. In other words, ask 5 billion people the same question and you won't get 100% either.

Garbage in = garbage out! This could not be more true in GenAI. If you data, assumptions or instructions are poor, expect S**t

And how many times I've heard:

Bus:"Lets put AI to solve the problem"

Tech:"describe me the problem?"

Bus: "AI should"figure it out" 

If you can't even explain the problem you are trying to solve it will be impossible to solve it.

Also, AI is not band-aid

Putting AI on a messy process will get you, well, a messy process with AI...

NOW, let focus on the IDEATION problem....

There is a reason why EVERY SINGLE VENDOR out there is after the "business cases". Good, valid, appealing and above all universal use cases are HARD to come by.

The nature of the game is, try often, fail fast, big return will come over time

In that process of getting your feet wet, you will try and mature your AI budgeting process.

Also, from a development perspective, as it is highly volatile, we recommend and approach from IDEA to POC to MVP to eventually PRODUT. Stepping stones.

In the ideation process, you need to evaluate the ideas in FEASIBILITY and VALUE. Ideally the Easiest and that will drive most business value will come to the top.

 

And how do you get there? 

Representation = You need tech folks who know the tech capabilities WITH the business folks who know the current business challenges.

Approach = BOTTOM UP approach is one where the ideation is around ideas to improve current processes while a BOTTOM UP approach is one where we re-think the process entirely with the new possibilities this technology brings

Also, effective enterprises adopt AI in 3 strategic levels

While company sets corporate wide transformational initiatives, departments should have their own plans and internal investments complemented by individuals trained and empowered to drive innovation in their own day to day.

The importance of OCM - Organizational Change Management

 

Lets talk beyond the BUILD phase

Cost reporting

You have 75 agents, each calling several LLMs cycles called by 2500 users. How much is it costing? who should pay for it? What is the ROI?

Helping value realization

You can only sucessfully demonstrate value if you determine a KPI, set a target and prove progress.

First determine a goal or a measurable outcome, establish a target and put in place what is required to measure it.

Only then, you will be able to demonstrate return on your investment (or not).

Understand now why 95% AI pilots fail ? ğŸ˜‰

entry.title: Wrap up SAP Inside Track Melbourne - 26th Nov 25
entry.content:
Thank you to the SAP Community members who came out in force to support the SAP Inside Track event for the fourth and final event of 2025, on 26th Nov.

We had two awesome presentations on

  1. Unleashing the power of AI agents with Joule Studio - Yatsea Li from SAP
  2. Building Intelligent SAP Skills with Joule Studio - Daljeet Singh from FAIR Consultingâ€ƒ

Both the topics were very engaging and knowledge enriching and peek into how we can use Joule Studio and some of it limitations. 

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

We would like to thank our friends at AWS for hosting us and providing the drinks and to SAP Press (@sappress) for their continued sponsorship.

â€ƒ

Congratulations to Priya Halderkoley and Maggie MA who were this quarters SAP Press book winners

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

Following are the planned dates for 2026 , please send us a email to sapsitmelbourne@gmail.com with your expression of interest to present at one of the following events. 

14th Mar 2026 - Full Day event 

20th May 2026 -  Tech night

19th Aug 2026 -  Tech night 

19th Nov 2026 - Tech night

 

Thank you 

Cheers,

SAP Melbourne Community

ç¾å ´ã®å®Ÿæƒ…ã¨ã—ã¦ã‚‚ã€20å¹´ä»¥ä¸Šå®‰å®šç¨¼åƒã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹BAPIã‚’ã€å˜ã«ã€ŒTier 1ã®ä½œæ³•ã§ã¯ãªã„ã€ã¨ã„ã†ç†ç”±ã ã‘ã§ä½œã‚Šç›´ã™ã“ã¨ã¯ã€ã‚³ã‚¹ãƒˆå¯¾åŠ¹æœã®é¢ã§æ­£å½“åŒ–ã§ãã¾ã›ã‚“ã€‚

å®Ÿã¯ã€ã“ã†ã—ãŸå£°ã‚’ä¸Šã’ã¦ã„ãŸã®ã¯æ—¥æœ¬ã®ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ã ã‘ã§ã¯ãªã‹ã£ãŸã‚ˆã†ã§ã™ã€‚ãƒ‰ã‚¤ãƒ„ã®DSAGã‚„ã‚¢ãƒ¡ãƒªã‚«ã®ASUGã¨ã„ã£ãŸä¸–ç•Œä¸­ã®ä¸»è¦ãªãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ã‚°ãƒ«ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‹ã‚‰ã‚‚ã€ã€Œæ—¢å­˜ã®å®‰å®šã—ãŸBAPIè³‡ç”£ã¾ã§å¦å®šã™ã‚‹ã®ã¯ç¾å®Ÿçš„ã§ã¯ãªã„ã€ã€ŒTier 2ã®ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒ‘ãƒ¼ä½œæˆã¯ç„¡é§„ãªå·¥æ•°ã ã€ã¨ã„ã£ãŸåŒæ§˜ã®ãƒ•ã‚£ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒãƒƒã‚¯ãŒå¯„ã›ã‚‰ã‚Œã¦ã„ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

ã“ã†ã—ãŸä¸–ç•Œä¸­ã®ãƒ¦ãƒ¼ã‚¶ãƒ¼ã‚³ãƒŸãƒ¥ãƒ‹ãƒ†ã‚£ã®ã€Œç¾å ´ã®å£°ã€ã‚’å—ã‘ã€SAPã¯2024å¹´ã‹ã‚‰2025å¹´ã«ã‹ã‘ã¦æ–¹é‡ã‚’è»Œé“ä¿®æ­£ã—ã€ã‚ˆã‚Šç¾å®Ÿçš„ã§æ´—ç·´ã•ã‚ŒãŸ**ã€ŒClean Core Extensibility Levelsï¼ˆA-Dãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ï¼‰ã€**ã¨ã„ã†æ–°ãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã‚’å°å…¥ã—ã¾ã—ãŸã€‚

(â€»å„ãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã®è©³ç´°ãªå®šç¾©ã¨3-Tierãƒ¢ãƒ‡ãƒ«ã¨ã®æ¯”è¼ƒã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã¯ã€æœ¬ç¨¿æœ«å°¾ã®Appendixã‚’å‚ç…§ãã ã•ã„)

    • Understanding DORA: A DevOps Guide for Side-by-Side Extension Developers: Googleã®DevOpsç ”ç©¶ï¼ˆDORAï¼‰ã‚’SAP BTPé–‹ç™ºã«é©ç”¨ã—ã€ãƒ‡ãƒªãƒãƒªãƒ¼ãƒ‘ãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚’æ¸¬å®šã™ã‚‹æ–¹æ³•ã«ã¤ã„ã¦ã®è§£èª¬ã€‚

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/understanding-dora-a-devops-guide-for-side-by-side-extension-developers/ba-p/14226907)

 

** Is "Clean Core" Really a New Concept? â€” Unraveling it by Revisiting the Past**

(â€»This article is a personal opinion based on my experience as an opinion leader of the JSUG Technical SIG, and does not represent the official views of the individual's company or organizations such as JSUG. Also, parts of the document were created using generative AI. We cannot guarantee the accuracy of the content, so please use the information at your own discretion.)

"Haven't We Said This Before?"

Through my activities with the JSUG (Japan SAP User Group) Technical Committee, I spend my days talking with fellow user companies and SAP experts. Recently, not a day goes by without hearing the words "Clean Core" at conferences. Iâ€™m sure many of you feel the same.

However, for those of us who have been in the SAP world for a long time, doesn't this bring about a certain sense of dÃ©jÃ  vu?

  • "Use standard functions for non-differentiating processes (Fit to Standard)"... Current

  • "If you build add-ons, use standard interfaces like BAPI"... A little while ago

  • "Stop directly modifying standard code (Modifications) because it hinders upgrades"... About 20 years ago

These are the "ideal states" we have been discussing and aiming for over the last 10, or even 20 years. While the terminology has changed, I feel the broad direction hasn't fundamentally shifted.

Recently, a participant in our committee asked me a probing question:

"SAP often talks about 'Clean Core,' but when can we actually say a system is 'Clean'? I want a convincing evaluation metric."

At that moment, I couldn't give an immediate answer. Simply saying, "We moved add-ons outside (Side-by-Side) and are only using public APIs," didn't feel satisfying. How is that fundamentally different from the architectures of the past where external VB or Java apps called BAPIs? I felt a frustration in being unable to clearly articulate the difference.

In this post, I want to organize this "unchanging essence," the evolution to the latest extensibility model (A-D Levels), and the new meaning in the AI era to rethink the direction we should be heading.

(This article is written for the SAP Advent Calendar 2025, December 8th entry.)

 

 

Spaghetti That Just Changed Its Location

First, we must face the concern that "Clean Core" is walking on its own as a formal goal of simply "having no code inside the ERP."

In the global SAP community (including SAP Mentors), there are strict warnings against the practice of "Lift & Shift"â€”taking existing low-quality custom code and moving it to a cloud platform (SAP BTP) without refactoring (redesigning). This creates what is known as a "Distributed Monolith."

"Moving rubbish from your room to the garage doesn't mean the house is clean." â€” This quote from an overseas architect cuts to the core of the issue.

If you take complex logic and move it to the cloud as-is, executing massive amounts of API calls, performance will degrade, and troubleshooting during failures will become a nightmare. This could become a repeat of the history where we struggled with external system integrations in the past.

"Changing the location" where we build is not the goal. We must not lose sight of the true purpose: "How do we respond to business changes?"

 

 

From Stoic Ideal to Reality: Evolution from the 3-Tier Model to A-D Levels

Here, we must also touch upon SAP's recent strategic shift. Initially, the "3-Tier Extensibility Model" was presented as the implementation guideline for the Clean Core strategy.

  • Tier 1: Use only cloud-native public APIs (Clean)

  • Tier 2: Wrappers for when public APIs are unavailable (Conditionally Clean)

  • Tier 3: Traditional ABAP coding (Not Clean)

This model was extremely stoic, creating strong pressure that "anything other than the latest cloud practices (Tier 1) is unacceptable."

However, within the JSUG Technical Committee, we repeatedly questioned SAP on this point:

"BAPI (Business Application Programming Interface) is a standard interface provided and guaranteed by SAP itself to safely extend standard functions. Isn't it contradictory to label it 'Not Clean' when we are using SAP's own standard?"

From a practical standpoint, forcing a rewrite of BAPIs that have been running stably for over 20 years, simply because they "don't fit Tier 1 practices," cannot be justified in terms of cost-effectiveness.

It turns out we weren't alone. Major user groups worldwide, such as DSAG in Germany and ASUG in the US, provided similar feedback: "Denying existing stable BAPI assets is unrealistic" and "Creating Tier 2 wrappers is wasted effort."

In response to these "voices from the field" from user communities globally, SAP corrected its course between 2024 and 2025, introducing a more realistic and sophisticated new model: "Clean Core Extensibility Levels (A-D Levels)."

(For detailed definitions of each level and a comparison with the 3-Tier model, please refer to the Appendix at the end of this article.)

 

 

A New Evaluation Axis: The Impact of A-D Levels

LevelVerdictDefinition and Interpretation from the Field
Level ACleanInvestment for the Future. The ideal form using the latest ABAP Cloud and Released APIs. New developments should aim for this.
Level BCleanThe Return of BAPI. This is crucial. The use of traditional BAPIs and IDocs (Classic APIs) has been officially recognized as part of "Clean Core." While not "cloud-native," they were evaluated as "Upgrade Safe."
Level CConditionalMonitor Required. Uses non-public internal objects, but risks can be managed via Changelogs, etc.
Level DNot CleanRed Zone. Modifications (direct changes to standard code) and direct table updates. This is the "true technical debt" that must be eliminated.

I evaluate this evolution as SAP prioritizing "substantive system stability" over "formal novelty," thereby regaining engineering integrity. The fact that BAPIs are recognized as "Clean" (even if at a certain level) maintains consistency with the past, providing a significant and realistic solution for us user companies migrating existing assets (Brownfield).

 

 

Why "Standardization" Again Now? â€” AI as the "New Evaluator"

Just because BAPI usage is allowed (Level B) doesn't mean we should continue with old-school add-on development habits. There is a decisive difference from the past: the "Rise of AI."

In the past, the ones interpreting the data generated by our unique add-on functions were "humans" who were trained to understand it. Humans could supplement "context" to work around slightly malformed data structures.

However, Generative AI (like SAP Joule) is different.

For AI to correctly interpret data and provide smart answers, the data model must be standard, and its meaning (Semantics) must be defined. Here, the relationship between "Z-tables (Add-on tables)" and "CDS Views" becomes critical.

 

Technical Deep Dive: Why Does AI Hate "Z-Tables"?

  • The Limit of Z-Tables (Lack of Context)

    The add-on tables (Z-tables) we have built for years are, to AI, just "mysterious data boxes." For example, if there is a column named VAL1 in a table called Z_SALES_TBL, the program logic might treat it as an order amount, but the database definition itself holds no such meaning.

    If AI looks at this table, it can't understand "what VAL1 is." It will either give a wrong answer (Hallucination) or say "I can't answer."

  • The Role of CDS Views (Injecting Meaning)

    In contrast, CDS (Core Data Services) Views, recommended in S/4HANA, attach "Semantic Labels" to data.

    By defining semantics like "This field is a 'Currency Code'," AI can understand the meaning of the data without looking inside the program logic.

In other words, the modern definition of "Clean" has shifted. It's not just about whether the code sits on BTP (Level A) or S/4HANA (Level B); it's about "whether your data is in a state that is 'interpretable' (Semantic Rich) by AI and the outside world through CDS Views."

 

 

"3 New Yardsticks" to Evaluate Your System

To answer the user's questionâ€”"How should we evaluate it?"â€”I would like to share the following evaluation axes based on a business perspective, premised on SAP's A-D Levels (technical indicators).

 

1. Business Fit & Metabolism

It's not just "Are we using standard functions?", but "Can we make the decision to discard functions that don't generate competitiveness?"

In terms of the A-D model, thoroughly eliminate Level D (Modifications), and even for Level B (BAPI), discard (Retire) those with low business value. This "metabolism" is what matters.

The "6R" Decluttering

  • Retire: Most important. Discard unused code.

  • Repurchase: Switch to SaaS or standard functions.

  • Refactor: Rebuild only differentiating areas in Level A (ABAP Cloud/BTP).

  • Re-platform: Recognize Level B (Classic API) as status quo. However, a repayment plan is needed.

 

2. Delivery Agility (Speed & Safety)

It's not "Are we using BTP?", but "Has the frequency of functional releases improved?"

If you are developing on the cloud but the lead time for a release takes months, the architecture or process is wrong. Like DORA metrics, use metrics like Change Lead Time and Deployment Frequency as your guide.

More Detail: Moving from "Developer's Intuition" to a "Decision Map (Framework)"

When considering agility, it is also necessary to examine architecture and the technologies adopted. In response to the question, "Should this function be built inside S/4HANA (On-Stack) or out on BTP (Side-by-Side)?", SAP provides a standard decision-making guide called the "SAP Application Extension Methodology (AEM)."

  • Phase 1: Is an extension actually necessary in the first place? (Decomposition of business requirements)

  • Phase 2: Is the need for UI, logic, or data? (Evaluation of technical characteristics)

  • Phase 3: Which technology is the optimal solution? (Decision via Decision Tree)

These can help maintain a consistent architecture as an organization.

Furthermore, to prevent development on BTP from becoming a "lawless zone," "Golden Paths" are essential. To explain this descriptively, you can think of it as a set that combines "development standards" and "development guidelines" (which are mainly documents and rules) with concrete "mechanisms" to actually streamline and automate the work. In this context, active consideration should be given to utilizing new (modern) technologies such as the following:

  • Write Declaratively (CAP/RAP): Instead of writing extensive procedural steps as done traditionally, shift to a style using CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model) or RAP (ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model) to define "data models and intent." This reduces code volume and increases affinity with AI.

  • Make Loosely Coupled (Event Mesh): Instead of tightly binding systems with APIs, adopt an event-driven architecture to reduce dependencies between systems.

 

3. Data & AI Readiness

"Is your company's data managed in a state that AI can understand?"

Are major data points accessible via standard tables or CDS Views (Semantic Views)? Regardless of whether the implementation is Level A or B, whether the data model has semantic definitions will be the watershed moment for future AI utilization.

 

 

Conclusion: The Essence is "Organization Based on Business Goals"

Looking only at the superficial meaning of the word "Clean Core" is dangerous. What is truly needed is the principleâ€”"organizing what to use (Standard) and what to make (Differentiation) based on business goals." This is an extremely obvious, yet difficult-to-execute principle.

The fact that SAP shifted its policy from the 3-Tier model to the A-D model and reinstated BAPI is a result of us, the user community, raising our voices and engaging in dialogue with the vendor. Without community discussion, idealistic theories detached from reality might have remained the rule.

"Clean Core" initiatives are not just about code on ECC, but a problem for the entire enterprise system. Furthermore, it is not a one-time initiative just for the timing of the upgrade from ECC.

The introduction of the A-D model and the recognition of existing asset utilization (Level B), including BAPI, is good news for us as it "lowers the hurdle for migration evaluation." However, we must not be complacent and leave systems "pickled" in their old state. This is because AI, the new "evaluator," is constantly questioning the quality of system data.

Completing this principle, which has flowed continuously since the era of BAPI integration, not as a technical theory but as a fundamental and management theory because we now have the new weapon of AIâ€”that is the path to the "True Clean Core" we should aim for.

I hope that this place (SAP Community) and user communities like JSUG continue to be places that do not just accept idealisms or buzzwords, but bring together these on-the-ground realities to fight out essential debates and deepen our collective knowledge.

I would be very happy to hear your opinions on this matter as well.

Finally, I would like to use this space to express my gratitude to the opinion leaders who always engage in and deepen these debates, the SAP folks who support us, the SAP Community members who provide new insights, and K.U. who gave me this "Question." (And also to the AI assistant who ran around gathering information and answering my doubts.)

Appendix: Report Summary

Paradigm Shift in Extensibility Models for SAP S/4HANA Clean Core Strategy

The following are the key points from the research report that formed the basis of this article:

1. Background and Issues

The traditional "3-Tier Model" had a strong tendency to label anything other than cloud-native (Tier 1) as "Not Clean," making it difficult for Japanese companies with large amounts of stable existing ABAP assets to implement. User communities like JSUG pointed out the contradiction that "even extensions using BAPI, an SAP standard function, are denied."

2. Detailed Definition of New Model (A-D Levels)

SAP redefined extensibility into four maturity levels and presented practical operational guidelines.

  • Level A (Clean Core / Future Safe):

    • Definition: Uses only Released APIs. Implementation on ABAP Cloud or BTP.

    • Recommendation: First choice for new development. Optimal for AI utilization.

  • Level B (Clean Core / Upgrade Safe):

    • Definition: Extensions using Classic APIs (BAPI, IDoc, RFC, etc.) and Classic Frameworks (ALV, Dynpro, etc.).

    • Difference from 3-Tier: This is the core of the paradigm shift. In the 3-Tier model, these were considered "Tier 3 (Not Clean)" or required concealment as "Tier 2 (Wrapper Creation)."

    • Innovation: In the new model, directly calling BAPIs without creating wrappers has been officially certified as "Clean Core". This means that a massive amount of existing code, which was considered "stable but not cloud-ready because it's old," now reaches the passing grade without modification.

  • Level C (Conditional / Monitor):

    • Definition: Extensions using non-public internal objects but are permitted provided risks are monitored and managed via change logs (Changelog / SYCM).

    • Difference from 3-Tier: The gray zone, which was uniformly considered "Tier 3 (Prohibited)" in the past, has been given the right to exist as "Managed Risk". It functions as a realistic workaround when no alternative API exists.

  • Level D (Not Clean / High Risk):

    • Definition: Modifications, direct table updates. Immediate elimination/renovation is required.

3. Strategic Implications

Level B certification allows for alleviating cost pressures in Brownfield migrations while concentrating resources on eliminating Level D (true debt). This represents a shift from "ideal" to "realistic solution," enhancing the effectiveness of the Clean Core strategy.

Reference Information & Related Links

The following discussions and materials were referenced in writing this article. Please use them for deeper learning.

  • Critical Considerations on Clean Core

    • â€œKeep the core cleanâ€ statement considered harmful (Wout de Waal's Blog): A must-read article sounding the alarm on the misunderstandings invited by "Clean Core" and the complexity of distributed systems (Distributed Monolith).

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/quot-keep-the-core-clean-quot-statement-considered-harmful/ba-p/13568928)

  • SAP Official Clean Core & Extension Strategy (A-D Model)

    • Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud (SAP Whitepaper): The official whitepaper defining the latest extension models (Clean Core Levels A-D) and governance.

    • (https://www.sap.com/documents/2024/09/20aece06-d87e-0010-bca6-c68f7e60039b.html)

  • Criteria for System Extension

    • SAP Application Extension Methodology: The official methodology and decision tree for deciding "Should we build On-Stack or Side-by-Side?".

    • (https://help.sap.com/docs/sap-btp-guidance-framework/sap-application-extension-methodology/sap-application-extension-methodology-overview)

  • Agility Evaluation Metrics (DORA Metrics)

    • Understanding DORA: A DevOps Guide for Side-by-Side Extension Developers: An explanation on applying Google's DevOps research (DORA) to SAP BTP development to measure delivery performance.

    • (https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/understanding-dora-a-devops-guide-for-side-by-side-extension-developers/ba-p/14226907)

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: singing, acting, advocating and... supporting
entry.content:
Who I am 

My name is Marika Porto, and I work as a Technical Lead Consultant at Mindset, an italian SAP Silver Partner company.
Special thanks to @JanRumig for passing the word on to me - and @smarchesini for pushing me, every day, to get out of my comfort zone a little more ğŸ˜‰ 
Today, Iâ€™d like to share a bit about my hobbies, joining the amazing  SAP Community Hobbies series. 
I have quite a few of them, and I hope some of you might share at least one with me! 
My hobbies play an important role in my life because they help me clear my mind and think more effectively, especially when I face challenging situations at work.
 

Why I decide to sing so awfully that even the clouds start crying

One of my favorite hobbies is singing! About a year ago, I started taking weekly singing lessons with a teacher, and itâ€™s honestly one of the best things Iâ€™ve done for myself lately. Singing has given me a ton of satisfactionâ€”especially because Iâ€™ve had the courage to perform in front of bigger crowds (over a hundred people!), a song in Sicilian language. 
 
For me, singing is a way to truly connect with myself and focus only on the feelings in my body, which is something I hardly get to do in my daily work life. Paying attention to my tone, volume, and how I position my mouth and lips forces me to be mindful and listen to whatâ€™s going on inside me. Sometimes it hurts, but this self-awareness is such a bonus, both personally and even at workâ€”itâ€™s a great stress reliever and confidence booster! Plus, I like to think Iâ€™m not too bad at it: my husband hasnâ€™t asked for a divorce yet, so I must be on the right track! ğŸ˜

 
This photo from my latest concert. in July 2025. I sang 'La Fine' - a song write by Francesco Tarducci (aka Nesli).
This song was hard to sing due to its introspective way: 'ArriverÃ  la fine, ma non sarÃ  la fine" - It will be the end... but I will never be
 

The best way to learn empathy: acting

My second big passion is acting!
I spend about four hours a week with a local theater group in my city called Lampioni Stortiâ€”they're super welcoming, even though I have a strong Southern Italian accent and they're all Northerners.
They've let me dive into everything behind the scenes: the training, prep, and all the hard work that goes into staging a comedy. So my gap become something really special, at the end.
 
Acting is huge for me because it teaches real empathyâ€”you have to fully step into someone else's shoes and live their story. And since we do comedies, nothing beats hearing the audience laugh; it's pure magic!
 
Next year, I'll even get my shot at a proper acting role, which I'm thrilled about.
 
It was a lot of fun, on March 2025, being the most annoying girlfriend possible in a play.
The audience identified so much that at a certain point they actually started hating me!
But I have to say, I'm pretty good as a blonde... 
 

M71A for women's equality in tech

My third hobbyâ€”and the one I'm most proud ofâ€”is being an activist for M71A, the Italian Manifesto for Equality of Girls and Women in Technology. It's a volunteer-driven group focused on gender equality in tech, tackling the gender gap and the challenges women face breaking through in our industry. Our big goal is cultural awareness to push for real change.
 
I got involved because I want to do my part, especially in the SAP world where I work daily. It's inspiring to fight for a more inclusive tech space where talent shines regardless of gender. 
 
Iâ€™d love to be a role model for someoneâ€”especially a female role model in techâ€”just like the incredible women who inspired me during my career to dive into technology and SAP. Seeing strong female leaders made all the difference, pushing me to pursue this path despite the challenges. Now, through my activism, I hope to pay it forward and encourage the next generation of women in our field to break barriers and thrive.
 
That's the badge that you can share if you sign the Manifesto. A way to be proud to be part of a important wind of change.

Being a sports supporter = pursuing a common goal together

My fourth hobbyâ€”and probably the most fun of allâ€”is being a die-hard volleyball fan! From October through March or April, I join the organized supporters group, named "Men In Black Group", for Pallavolo Padova, one of Italy's top SuperLega teams (the premier men's league). Sundays mean chanting new cheers, losing my voice, and dealing with Monday morning throat pain, all while surrounded by a huge crowd with different vibes but the same fiery passion.
 
It's chaos in the best wayâ€”coordinating with fans who all want different things but pull together for one goal. Being in that energy reminds me how powerful it is to spot a shared objective and row in the same direction, a lesson that translates straight to teamwork at work. 
Being a supporter doesn't mean to join a violent group of people: it's just the opposite. You are in the right place with people that respect the opposite players. No scream, no shout, only positives happy vibes!
And when your favorite team loses, we all think about next time, because there's always a next time.
If you persist and persevere, you'll achieve and conquer!
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
A happy me beating the drum to support the team.
About two hours of play where the only thought is pushing the boys to never give up, as a leader must do everyday!

How to get started and how to achieve your first goals with these hobbies

To get started as a beginner in any of these hobbies, the key essentials aren't gear or fancy resourcesâ€”they're curiosity to dive in and the courage to put yourself out there, facing some of your biggest fears head-on.
 
Things like public speaking, expressing raw emotions, or sharing what you truly care about can feel scary at first, but pushing through builds real confidence that spills over into work and life. Start small, practice with people you trust, and breathe deeply to stay groundedâ€”it's all about that first step of getting uncomfortable to grow.
 
Any actor, singer, activist, supporter out there?
Let's chat!
 
Love from Marika

entry.title: My SAP TechEd 2025: Special SAP Community Moments
entry.content:
Hello everyone!

My name is Moshe Naveh from the SAP Community team. Today I would like to share with you the exceptional experience I had in SAP TechEd Berlin and Bangalore 2025. There isn't a more suitable day to do so but my 16th SAP Community anniversary which is today. Joining the SAP Community back in 2009 enabled me to attend multiple SAP TechEds as Iâ€™ve shared in this post. However, this year was my best SAP TechEd year so far! Want to know why? please keep reading below:).

Before we dive into the details of my amazing SAP TechEd 2025 journey, I would like to invite you to an online gathering where we will continue the SAP TechEd magic! SAP Community members will share their personal SAP TechEd experience and highlights and also learn how to quickly share it on the SAP Community using the AI based Simplified blogging methodology. If you're interested in joining, please Email me at community@sap.com and I'll send you more details (currently we're planning for upcoming Thursday, but we'll see what works for everyone).

SAP TechEd Berlin

SAP TechEd Berlin was my first SAP TechEd event after 7 years. That was the case for many people. You could really feel how eager people were to meet again in person. There is something in face to face meeting that you cannot sense via a virtual interaction. During the event I was mainly in the SAP Community booth. It enabled me to do something I really enjoy when meeting SAP Community members and that is to interact, share ideas and insights, smile and laugh and just have good time together. It is what the SAP Community and my community passion is all about. I was also very happy to meet community members who participated in our SAP TechEd speakers series and hear how the simplified methodology helped them:

Sunny Kapoor who spoke about Real-time data for AI agents: Grounding with event-driven architecture

and 

Stephanie Jerch and Christian Niedermayer who had a session about "Discover SAP Cloud ALM for operations in action"

Then I really enjoyed also telling people about the SAP Community Hobbies series and even got some new contributors to join it!

Marla Alschweiki who will share about her lovely dog and more!

And 

Patricia who will share about her lovely hobbies (more details to come!:))

I was also fortunate to finally meet in person community members I've been working with for years, such as KP who does terrific things related to database and analytics in the SAP Community 

One my main challenge during the event was not to eat too much (remember this line! You will hear it again)!

We had a great photographer on site who helped people get their perfect profile picture!:  

 I think it came out nice;):

and talking about photos, one of the things you wonder about during such events after you have not been to them for a while is what changed. I know Christian Braukmuller didn't change!: 

     Exact spot, 11 years and not much changed:)

One of the most important aspects for me in such events is meeting my team! 

Here in the picture awesome SAP Community members and some of my amazing team members, among those responsible for the great community magic during SAP TechEd (including team members not in the picture, holding the fortress back in the office:)) 

      

 

And I couldn't ask for a better last selfie for SAP TechEd Berlin just before I headed home:

         

SAP TechEd Berlin was great and prepared me for the wow experience I was about to have in SAP TechEd Bangalore.

 

SAP TechEd Bangalore

 

So after two weeks break at home, I was fortunate to travel again to SAP TechEd Bangalore. I haven't been to India for a long time as well and I enjoyed every moment in it:).

One of the first things I did after I landed was to go and eat. I was both hungry but I also really missed the Indian food!

I went for the spiciest dish in the menu:

and here you can see the steam on sunglasses from how spicy the food was! (I thought it just happened in cartoons:)) :

Then, after resting a bit from the travel I've reached what I was really after and that was meeting everyone in SAP TechEd Bangalore!

I was so happy meeting everyone and I started taking selfies with SAP Community members to have a memory of those great meetings! Interestingly enough, the second person that I saw and knew, was Jitendra Kansal:

   

Jitendra is an old friend and we first me back in 2012 during my first SAP TechEd ever and after Jitendra was one of the main people who helped me successfully launch and expend the blog it forward challenge!:  

      

 then I got to my booth and I fell in love with the setup. I loved the big touch screen TV and space we got to freely interact and engage with amazing people. When I explained to people who heard about the community for the first time, I was excited as them. Showing different places on the community on the big touch screen made it feel to me like dancing!:

 

It was two amazing days where I didn't stop talking about the great things that are happening in the SAP Community. I met so many great people and existing/new friends. Not many know but it was the first time I did such an engaging interaction in the booth which included a lot of jokes and interesting stories about the SAP Community and myself. Josh Bentely well described as being an educational entertainer! I enjoyed so much talking about my passion to the SAP Community and at the same time making people happy and laugh:):

I admit that I was very moved by the energy and the great spirit of the next generation of the SAP Professionals:

And I also talked about the SAP Community hobbies and was able to prove to the world how go of a painter @Sandra_Solis is (whom I was very fortunate to meet with in Berlin and we agreed we won't forget to take a selfie next time:):

Vitaly is showing how he looks alike his coffee drawing by Sandra Solis

and another great photo filled with community spirit:

 

And talking about community spirit, the Developer advocates rocked it during the entire event (also in SAP TechEd Berlin):

I love the Indian culture! I love the people, food, music and dance! Couldn't think of a better way to finish my own personal SAP TechEd tour with a great show and dancing like no one is watching:):

So SAP TechEd 2025 was an amazing experience that we all, and especially me, were waiting for so long. I'm sure that you and I will see fruits of the great SAP Community booth interactions and that I will stay in touch with my new SAP Community friends.

Looking forward to seeing all of you in the SAP Community and in future events!

Please join us, SAP Community members and the Community team for an SAP Teched gathering where we will connect, share experiences and learn how to quickly share them in the SAP Community. Please Email me at community@sap.com if you would like to join the gathering.

Please share in the comments section how was SAP TechEd for you and if you have picture of us together, please share!:)

ã‚¯ãƒªãƒ¼ãƒ³ã‚³ã‚¢ã®ï¼•åŸå‰‡

 

#ã€€

ã‚¯ãƒªãƒ¼ãƒ³ã‚³ã‚¢ã®5åŸå‰‡ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€

å†…å®¹ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€

1

(ãƒ“ã‚¸ãƒã‚¹ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ã‚¹)

o     æ¨™æº–ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ã‚¹ã‚’æœ€å¤§é™æ´»ç”¨ã—ã€å·®åˆ¥åŒ–ãŒå¿…è¦ãªéƒ¨åˆ†ã®ã¿æ‹¡å¼µã€‚ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€ã€€

entry.title: A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025
entry.content:
A Day of Innovation, Insight & Intelligent Conversations: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 was more than an event â€” it was a full day of learning, exchange of ideas, and meaningful community moments. Hosted with the support of AWS, Mindset, ROJO Integrations, and SAP Press, the gathering brought together professionals from across the SAP ecosystem: developers, consultants, architects, leaders, learners, and enthusiasts.

Right from the first interaction at the registration desk, there was a sense of purpose and curiosity in the air. Everyone walked in with a shared goal: to understand where the world of enterprise technology is heading next.

SAP GGN Community Core Team for SAP Insider Track GGN 2025 â€“ Third Edition

 

A Warm and Powerful Beginning

The day began with organized registrations and structured networking, giving participants the opportunity to connect and align their expectations for the event. The event kicked off with a warm welcome from Aseem Khera, Location Head, â€‹SAP Labs India Gurugramâ€‹ clearly outlining the agenda and highlighting the dayâ€™s objectives. His opening remarks established a clear framework and set the tone for subsequent sessions.

Aseem Khera, Location Head, â€‹SAP Labs India Gurugramâ€‹ 

 

This was followed by an inspiring video keynote from Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. In her address, she highlighted the importance of the SAP Community, the effects of artificial intelligence on the global economy, and SAP's AI-First, Suite-First strategy.

Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM

 

 

The morning session continued with an inspiring SAP Business AI strategy talk by Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture â€‹Private Cloud Products titled â€œTransforming Business with SAP Business AI.â€ He provided a comprehensive and insightful overview of the ongoing transformation of SAP Business AI strategy.

Sudhir Verma, Head of Technology & Architecture â€‹Private Cloud Products

 

A huge shout-out to our amazing host, Akansha Tiwari! Your energy, charm, and effortless hosting truly made the event unforgettable. Your poised and engaging presence kept the momentum alive throughout the entire morning session. The way you connected with the audience, guided transitions with ease, and maintained a vibrant atmosphere played a pivotal role in the eventâ€™s overall success.

 

Akansha Tiwari - Host of the Event

 

 

Three Tracks, Three Journeys, One Purpose

The event went beyond treating technology as a concept, organizing learning into three parallel tracks tailored to different participant needs. Each track offered practical, actionable insightsâ€”catering to leaders, developers, and hands-on learners alikeâ€”allowing attendees to explore strategies, tools, and real-world applications in a focused and meaningful way aligned with their roles and professional goals.

Agenda of the day with Session Title & Speaker Names

 

Track 01: SAP Business AI Strategy & Roadmapâ€‹ / SAP Business AI Products

Ideal for architects, leaders, and decision-makers

This track focused on understanding how organizations can evolve their systems, processes, and governance models. Speakers shared their experiences on:

  • Strengthening enterprise value
  • Navigating regulatory landscapes
  • Modernizing GRC
  • Evolving SuccessFactors experiences
  • Positioning SAPâ€™s latest offerings for business outcomes

The conversations werenâ€™t theoreticalâ€”they were grounded in real decisions and real impact.

 

Track 02: Embedded AI in SAP Solutionsâ€‹ / Building with SAP AI Agentsâ€‹

Built for developers, engineers, and product builders

This track showcased what happens when ideas take shape. From building custom solutions to exploring new toolkits, participants learned how to translate concepts into working applications.

Sessions covered:

  • Building custom agents
  • Optimizing catalogs
  • Ensuring safety in high-risk industries
  • Handling real-time situations in S/4HANA
  • Enhancing HR processes with modern tools

Every session was centered around solving real business challenges.

 

Track 03: Hands-On Workshops

For those who understand best by doing

This track remained one of the most crowded for a reasonâ€”it was all action.

Participants practiced:

  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from an imageâ€‹
  • Generate an SAP Fiori app from business requirementsâ€‹
  • Generate and enhance an appâ€‹
  • Develop an Enterprise-Grade CAPâ€‹

It was a genuine â€œroll-up-your-sleevesâ€ experience.

 

Afternoon Deep Dives: Practical Stories & Lessons

Post lunch, the sessions transitioned to in-depth case studies and practical, real-world scenarios. Speakers provided valuable insights on topics such as:

  • Detecting fraud within business systems
  • Optimizing development cycles
  • Managing responsible digital processes
  • Enhancing commercial operations
  • Improving employee experiences in live environments

These discussions effectively bridged technology with day-to-day organizational decisions, demonstrating tangible applications and measurable outcomes for participants.

 

The Heart of the Day: Conversations & Community

SAP Inside Track events have always been known for their community-driven spirit. Gurugram 2025 continued that legacy beautifully.

Corridors, break areas, and even the workshop tables stayed alive with:

  • Debates on implementation challenges
  • Exchange of tips and best practices
  • Discussions on new roles and skills
  • Shared excitement for the future of enterprise systems

For many, these conversations were just as valuable as the sessions themselves.

 

A Fitting Closure

The day wrapped up with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal networking. People walked out with new connections, refreshed perspectives, and a deeper appreciation for how powerful the SAP community is when it comes together.

[English Version]

Event Report: ASUG Tech Connect 2025: JSUG Technical Committee's Perspective on the SAP Ecosystem via Berlin and North America

Disclaimer:

This article represents the personal views of the author based on their experience as an Opinion Leader of the JSUG Technical Committee and does not represent the official views of their affiliated company or organizations such as JSUG. Parts of this document were created with the assistance of Generative AI. We do not guarantee the accuracy of the content, so please use the information at your own discretion.

This article is written for the SAP Advent Calendar 2025 (December 15th).

Introduction: Seeking the "Mainstream" of Technology and the "Heat Source" of Community

Recently, "ASUG Tech Connect 2025" was held in Louisville, Kentucky.

Although this is the third year for this event, we at the JSUG (Japan SAP Users' Group) Technical Committee have participated every year since its inception (2023), regularly monitoring the enthusiasm and trends on the ground.

This year, the JSUG Technical Committee took a strategic approach.

We dispatched two members to "SAP TechEd Berlin," the main event where SAP's latest technologies are announced, to catch up on the "mainstream" of technology. Meanwhile, we dispatched three members, including myself, to "ASUG Tech Connect" here in North America.

Why did we dare to split the team and travel to North America?

This event was born out of a strong local will that "a place for face-to-face gathering is necessary" when SAP TechEd in North America became virtual in the past. Although SAP TechEd has now returned to in-person formats, ASUG Tech Connect has undergone its own unique evolution as an event that prioritizes "the significance of people gathering" above all else.

The latest technology (Berlin) and its practice/community (ASUG).

We report on the collaboration with SAP TechEd and the message unique to ASUG regarding "Human Transformation," which became visible precisely because we dispatched members to both sides.

 

 

 

1. Powerful Collaboration with SAP TechEd Berlin: The "Perfect Companions" Across the Ocean

This year, ASUG Tech Connect was clearly defined as "The perfect companions" to SAP TechEd. This is because, as "The Official North American SAP TechEd Tour Event," it is completely synchronized with the global event in the following three points:

  • Sharing Content (Hands-on):

    Technical sessions and hands-on materials announced at SAP TechEd Berlin were provided as-is at the North American venue. For example, sessions on Generative AI and Fiori app development included guidance to "Try the hands-on from SAP TechEd Berlin," enabling the same technical experience as in Berlin while being in North America.

  • Providing Certification:

    The venue offered opportunities to obtain the latest SAP certifications such as "SAP Build Developer" and "SAP Generative AI Developer" at no additional cost.

  • Real-time Collaboration:

    In the keynote, SAP's Muhammad Alam participated via live broadcast from the SAP TechEd venue in Berlin. It was emphasized that both events are transmitting a unified message, transcending physical distance.

 

 

 

2. The Core of the Keynote: Transform "People" Rather Than Technology

The keynote, the highlight of the event, consisted of two parts: the "Opening" on the first day and the "Partner & Customer Stories" on the third day.

What ASUG CEO Geoff Scott and SAP leaders broadcasted here was a powerful message concerning our careers and the survival of our organizations, going beyond mere introductions of new features. This is the biggest difference from SAP TechEd, which focuses on technology announcements.

"Change has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow again"

First, I want to share a phrase that symbolizes the modern era, which was repeatedly cited throughout the event.

"Change has never been this fast, and it will never be this slow again"

We are now at a historical turning point.

In the customer panel, a fact was contrasted: "It took 500 years for Gutenberg's printing press to spread, whereas ChatGPT reached 1 million users in just 5 days."

Also, SAP's Mayank Shrivastava pointed out that the evolution cycle of AI models is at a "frightening pace," shortening from an update interval of about 10 months previously to just 7 weeks for the latest models.

In this "irreversible acceleration," how should we behave?

Discard "Yesterday" and Move to "Learn-it-all"

In response to this question, Dr. Walter Sun, SAP's Global Head of AI, presented two important guidelines.

  1. Stop Optimizing Yesterday

    "Stop optimizing what we have done yesterday."

    It is essential not to merely improve efficiency of existing processes with AI, but to rethink the processes themselves from the ground up and have the curiosity to experiment.

  2. From "Know-it-all" to "Learn-it-all"

    Then, "Learn-it-all" was presented as the mindset transformation.

    • Know-it-all: An attitude of clinging to past knowledge and being overconfident that one knows everything.

    • Learn-it-all: An attitude of trying to learn new things every day.

    Barriers to entry for AI are low, and anyone can try it immediately. That is why whether you can cycle through "Experimentation" becomes the dividing line for victory, rather than the amount of knowledge.

Support through Technology and Teams

Of course, it was not just about mindset. Concrete "weapons" and "cases" were also shared.

  • Weapons for Developers:

    Muhammad Alam and Yaad Oren stated that investment in a "Clean Data Layer (Business Data Cloud)" is paramount to respond to changes happening in 7-week units. Also, the opening of SAP Build (VS Code extensions, etc.) was announced to resolve backlogs, promising an environment where developers can fight using familiar tools.

  • Transformation is a Team Sport:

    In the keynote on the third day, cases such as PepsiCo (AI/Copilot utilization), HP (ERP modernization), and Int4 (test automation) were shared.

    In particular, the "Show and Tell" sessions by companies like John Deere demonstrated not just clean slides but the "gritty practical knowledge" of how the whole team overcame challenges, serving as a learning ground with reality unique to ASUG.

 

 

 

3. Analysis: What is the Difference Between SAP TechEd Berlin and ASUG Tech Connect?

Synthesizing the perspectives of JSUG members who participated in both Berlin and ASUG, we can see that while both events share the "Same Technology Strategy (What)," there is a clear division of roles in "Who they tell it to and How (Who & How)."

Commonalities (The "What")

Both events are completely aligned on technical core messages.

  • The Era of AI Agents: Focus on "Autonomous AI (Joule Agents)" beyond chatbots.

  • Openness to Developers: Fusion with open standard technologies such as SAP Build VS Code extensions.

  • Clean Core: Utilization of "Clean Data Layer" and BTP as the foundation for innovation.

Differences (The "Focus")

However, their focus differs significantly.

FeatureSAP TechEd Berlin (Global)ASUG Tech Connect (North America)
Catch MessageWhere ideas get real.Real Skills. Real People. Real Impact.
Main Focus"Technology and Roadmap""Professional Transformation"
Perspective on AIFunctionality and Possibility (What AI can do)Responsibility and Skills (How humans use AI)
Case StudiesShowcase of SAP TechnologySharing Gritty Practical Knowledge (Show and Tell)
DirectionVendor to User (Vision)User to User Mutual Aid (Community)

In other words, while Berlin is a place to hand over the "Latest Weapons (Technology)," ASUG Tech Connect can be said to be a place to nurture the "Users (People)."

 

 

 

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

â€ƒ

Summary: Let's Energize the Japanese Community Precisely Because We Share the Same Struggles

"Business transformation does not happen without professional transformation"

This phrase was spoken by ASUG CEO Geoff Scott in the opening keynote of ASUG Tech Connect.

Implementing technology (AI or S/4HANA) alone does not change business. It is an absolute condition for success that we, who handle it, discard old habits and acquire new skills and mindsets (= professional transformation).

However, while we individuals have hope for capability expansion through AI, I think there is also anxiety about being required to transform into a constantly learning "Learn-it-all."

Furthermore, looking at organizations, we face walls that are not easily overcome, such as data preparation, cultural acceptance, and security responsibilities.

Through this participation, I found a certain "reality" that I desperately want to convey to you all.

While touching on the latest technology at the venue, networking with ASUG Community members revealed unexpected words from them.

"We are busy with the maintenance of existing systems and cannot get around to new technologies."

"We know transformation is necessary, but the organization doesn't follow."

Even engineers in North America, which is said to be an IT-advanced region, were actually facing exactly the same worries as us and fighting ongoing problems.

The keynote's warning that "Change has never been this fast" was a heavy reality for them as well.

We are not alone. And it is not just Japan that is lagging behind.

Now that the whole world is facing the same wall, the meaning of the question thrown by ASUG CEO Geoff Scott resonates even more strongly.

"Why go alone when we can go together?"

No matter how excellent individual skills are, the risk of fighting in isolation in this torrent is too great.

Just as users in North America are gathering at ASUG to support each other, we also need to strengthen the power of the Japanese community more.

There are diverse "places to connect" in Japan: not just the SAP Community here, but also external study groups, online forums, partner communities, and user groups like ours.

We will share the insights we grabbed in Berlin and North America through various opportunities. Let's energize the entire Japanese community, share wisdom with each other (Collective wisdom), and ride over this wave of change together.

I look forward to heating up the discussion with you all at various community venues.

entry.title: Hello SAP Community Chemnitz
entry.content:
*** english below ***

Willkommen in der SAP Community Local Group Chemnitz!

Diese Gruppe ist eine lokale Plattform fÃ¼r alle, die sich in Chemnitz und der Region fÃ¼r SAP interessieren. Ganz gleich, ob du tÃ¤glich mit SAP-LÃ¶sungen arbeitest, als Berater:in, Entwickler:in oder Analyst:in tÃ¤tig bist, studierst oder einfach neugierig auf SAP-Themen bist â€“ du bist hier herzlich willkommen.

Unser Ziel ist es, einen Raum fÃ¼r persÃ¶nlichen Austausch und Vernetzung zu schaffen. Wir sind Ã¼berzeugt davon, dass der direkte Austausch von Angesicht zu Angesicht besonders wertvoll ist, um Erfahrungen zu teilen, Ideen zu diskutieren und voneinander zu lernen.

Chemnitz und die umliegende Region bieten eine starke Basis aus Industrie, Technologie und Innovation, ergÃ¤nzt durch eine vielfÃ¤ltige akademische Landschaft mit Hochschulen und Forschungseinrichtungen als wichtigen Teil des lokalen Ã–kosystems. Wir mÃ¶chten Menschen aus Industrie, Beratung, Wissenschaft und darÃ¼ber hinaus miteinander vernetzen.

Unser erster Fokus liegt klar auf persÃ¶nlichen Treffen vor Ort. Geplant sind entspannte Meetups und informelle ZusammenkÃ¼nfte wie ein Stammtisch, bei denen sich SAP-Interessierte und SAP-Professionals austauschen, voneinander lernen und gemeinsam ein starkes lokales Netzwerk aufbauen kÃ¶nnen. Informationen zu kommenden Veranstaltungen teilen wir hier in der Gruppe.

Diese Community lebt von der Beteiligung ihrer Mitglieder. Alle, die die Idee des offenen Austauschs und der Zusammenarbeit teilen, sind eingeladen, sich einzubringen, Themen vorzuschlagen oder zukÃ¼nftige Events mitzugestalten. Wenn du dich aktiver an der Organisation oder Kuration der Gruppe beteiligen mÃ¶chtest, melde dich gern.

Wir freuen uns darauf, eine lebendige SAP Community in Chemnitz aufzubauen und viele spannende GesprÃ¤che persÃ¶nlich vor Ort zu fÃ¼hren.

Willkommen in der Gruppe!

Viele GrÃ¼ÃŸe
Pierre und Jens

Welcome to the SAP Community Local Group Chemnitz!

This group is a local platform for everyone in and around Chemnitz who is interested in SAP. Whether you work with SAP solutions in your daily business, are a consultant, developer, analyst, student, or simply curious about SAP topics, you are very welcome to join us.

Our main goal is to create a space for personal exchange and networking. We strongly believe in the value of meeting face to face, sharing experiences directly, and discussing challenges and ideas in an open and relaxed atmosphere.

Chemnitz and the surrounding region offer a strong foundation of industry, technology, and innovation, supported by a diverse academic landscape with universities and research institutions as an important part of the local ecosystem. We want to connect people from industry, consulting, academia, and beyond who are part of this ecosystem.

Our first focus is clearly on meeting in person. We are planning relaxed meetups and informal get-togethers (Stammtisch) where SAP professionals and interested people can exchange ideas, learn from each other, and grow a strong local network. You will find updates on upcoming events right here in the group.

This community lives from participation. Everyone who shares the idea of open exchange and collaboration is invited to contribute, bring in topics, or help shape future events. If you are interested in getting more actively involved in organizing or curating the group, feel free to reach out.

We are looking forward to building a vibrant SAP community in Chemnitz and to many great conversations in person and on site.

Welcome to the group!

Best regards
Pierre and Jens

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: AI Insights, SAP Community Memories, and Whatâ€™s Coming in 2026!
entry.content:
Today marks the final edition of Community Voice for 2025, and we are happy to bring you great featured blog posts, valuable insights from one of our SAP Mentors, and wonderful memories from SAP TechEd. Looking back, we are incredibly proud of our SAP community members for their contributions, energy, and commitment to helping others, sharing experiences, and making the SAP ecosystem an inspiring place to be part of. 

This edition is also a moment to express our gratitude to you, our readers, who continuously engage with our content. Without your support and participation, none of this would be possible. Thank you for being here and for showing up to so many other community members. 

While this newsletter takes a short break during the holiday season, we want to let you know that we will be back at the beginning of January 2026. For now, letâ€™s look at what has been happening in the SAP Community over the past few weeks and what exciting events are planned for the year ahead! 

Letâ€™s dive in! 

Featured Blog Posts

Reflections about how far AI will go  

The more we talk about AI, the more people tend to pick sides. Whether you like it or not, the implementation of Artificial Intelligence is accelerating everywhere, and this year SAP demonstrated how well it is prepared to bring powerful AI solutions to its customers. SAP Community member and former SAP employee Pierre Col, who recently retired, opened an important discussion about this topic. In his blog post, he highlights how strongly SAP is positioned in the market and showcases the power of its AI offerings. At the same time, he raises concerns about the impact that AI, and humanoid robots in particular, may have on human employment. Overall, this is a valuable blog post that encourages thoughtful reflection on what the near future may look like and invites the community to share ideas, perspectives, and engage in meaningful discussion in the comments. 

Read Pierre full blog post here 

Guide to Accessibility in SAP Fiori/UI5 for beginners  

If you are looking to understand what accessibility really is in UI development, common pitfalls in UI5 apps and how to start building accessible features without feeling overwhelmed, this blog post is for you. SAPÂ´s Guruprasad, shares a personal journey of discovering why accessibility is not extra work, but a fundamental part of building usable applications, particularly when working with SAP Fiori and UI5. Through practical examples, he introduces useful tools and techniques for testing accessibility, including keyboard-only navigation, screen readers, contrast checkers, and browser inspection tools. This is a beginner-friendly and practical guide for everyone who wants to build inclusive, high-quality SAP UI applications.  

Read Guruprasad full blog post here 

SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo insights on AI journey at SAP TechEd 2025  

One of the most valuable aspects of SAP TechEd 2025 was the insightful sessions delivered by experienced developers and industry experts. We had the pleasure of hearing from many SAP Mentors and Champions who brought important conversations to the spotlight, and one of the standout sessions was presented by SAP Mentor Leonardo Araujo. His session was based on his earlier blog postâ€The AI Stack Is Ready â€” Are You? The Challenge No Longer Is Technologyâ€œ. Leonardo explained that the AI technology stack, especially for generative and agent-based AI, is already largely in place. Capabilities such as secure AI, RAG scenarios, agent building, orchestration, and flexible LLM choices are now well supported by SAP BTP and reinforced by recent SAP innovations announced at SAP TechEd. He also emphasized key realities of generative AI, including its probabilistic nature, the critical importance of clearly defined problem statements, and the risks of applying AI to broken or poorly designed processes. Therefore, Leonardo shared practical recommendations around experimentation, fail-fast approaches, and the journey from pilot to production. His content is a must-read, offering valuable insights into why some AI pilots fail and how organizations can achieve success. 

Read Leonardo Araujo full blog post here 

SAP Cloud ALM: Codeless Automation for RISE Transitions 

Nowadays, regression testing often becomes a challenge because of the necessity teams need to balance thorough test coverage with the pressure to release quickly. SAPÂ´s Paulo Boschetti explores how Tricentis Test Automation for SAP integrated with SAP Cloud ALM can help teams address this challenge in a more practical way. Paulo explains that tools only succeed when supported by strong testing practices, clear strategies, and skilled teams. While Tricentis TTA offers a powerful, codeless, and SaaS-based approach, its real value comes from enabling functional teams to actively participate in automation rather than replacing testing expertise. Considering real-world implementations in Latin America, particularly during RISE with SAP transitions and S/4HANA upgrades, he shows how this solution significantly reduces regression testing effort and accelerates delivery cycles. He also makes sure to remind readers toâ€¯invest equally in your team by training them and supporting skills development.  

Read Paulo Boschetti full blog post here 

Community News 

SAP TechEd 2025: Moshe Naveh Recap  

SAP TechEd 2025 was definitely a highlight of the year for the SAP Community, and Community Advocate Moshe Naveh shared an engaging recap of his experience, highlighting some of the great moments he spent with community members in Berlin and Bengaluru. In his blog post, he reflects on how refreshing it was to return to on-site events, especially since his last SAP TechEd attendance was seven years ago. Moshe also encourages community members to keep the momentum going through online gatherings and continued engagement. For those feeling inspired to share their own stories, he previously published a helpful guide on using an AI-based simplified blogging methodology, making it easier for anyone to start contributing and sharing their experiences with the community. 

SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025 

At the end of November, one of the most anticipated events for the SAP Community Gurugram location group took place: SAP Inside Track Gurugram 2025. The event offered a full day of learning and idea exchange among community members and SAP developers, consultants, architects and many more. Hosted at SAP Labs India in Gurugram, the event opened with a keynote by Sindhu Gangadharan, Managing Director of SAP Labs India, Head of SAP Customer Innovation Services, and SAP Chairperson of NASSCOM. Alongside the keynote, the agenda covered a wide range of SAP topics presented by multiple speakers and lots of network breaks. The day concluded with a closing ceremony followed by snacks and informal talks, giving attendees the opportunity to connect. If you would like to explore more highlights (or check if you appear in any of the photos) be sure to read SAPÂ´s Neeraj Manocha latest blog post here for a full recap of the SIT Gurugram! 

SAP ALM Summit North America 2026

To keep the energy going, we would like to remind everyone about the upcoming SAP ALM Summit North America 2026! This event is the chance to boost your ALM value by learning from real-life customer experiences. Expand your knowledge through hands-on labs and attending expert-led sessions.  Some of the amazing speakers that will be presenting at the event are Tim Steuer - VP Customer Communications & Relations SAP SE, SÃ¶ren Ruder- Head of Customer Experience & Solutions (CXS) SAP SE, Joshua Greenbaum- Principal of Enterprise Applications Consulting EAC and Todd Crandall- Head of Customer Services & Delivery SAP North America. Make sure to register for the event here: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026. 

2026 Upcoming Events

As 2025 comes to an end, we are already looking ahead to 2026 with many exciting plans! SAP community location groups have already added dates for upcoming gatherings to their agendas, giving you the perfect opportunity to mark your calendar early and plan ahead. These events are a great chance to connect, learn, and meet fellow SAP community members in your area.  

Check out the list below to see the events already scheduled for 2026: 

  • 20 of January: SAP CodeJam - Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Bielefeld, Germany) 
  • 21 of January: SAP CodeJam - Getting started with Generative AI Hub on SAP AI Core ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 22 of January: SAP CodeJam ABAP: SAP BTP, ABAP Environment & RAP ( Hyderabad, India ) 
  • 23 of January: SAP Stammtisch Wroclaw - January Edition! (Registration is closed) 
  • 29 of January: SAP Build: Advanced Event Mesh - Event based SAP Build Process Automation (Bengaluru, India) 
  • 09 of February: Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Pune, India) 
  • 26 of February: â€¯Build AI services using the CAP and Generative AI Hub (Gent, Belgium) 
  • 14 of March: SAP Inside Track Joinville 2026 â€“ Brasil 
  • 17 of March: SAP TALK WOMEN CWB 2026- Curitiba, Brasil 
  • 14 - 16 of April: SAP ALM Summit NA 2026- Pennsylvania, United States
  • 26 of September: SAP Inside Track Porto 2026 - Portugal 
  • 31 of October: SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2026- Brasil  

Happy Holidays!  

We would like to express our sincere gratitude to the entire SAP community for the passion, collaboration, and knowledge you share every day. Your contributions and willingness to support one another are what makes this community so special. 2025 was a wonderful year, filled with meaningful lessons and lasting memories, whether online or on-site. Every SAP Inside Track, Stammtisch, meet-up, and even informal conversation made a significant impact, strengthening our connections and contributing to the growth of our community. We wish you a joyful holiday season with peace, happiness, and time with loved ones. We look forward to continuing this journey together in 2026. Happy holidays from all of us in the SAP Community!
